text: STARK STATEMENT ON HOUSE VOTE TO DEFUSE THE MEDICARE TRIGGER
label: TITLE

text: Thursday, 24 July 2008
label: BODY

text: Rep. Pete Stark released the following remarks today after the House voted 231-184 to defuse the Medicare trigger for
label: BODY

text: this year.
label: BODY

text: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
label: BODY

text: Thursday, July 24, 2008
label: BODY

text: CONTACT: Brian Cook, 202-225-3202
label: BODY

text: STARK STATEMENT ON HOUSE VOTE TO DEFUSE THE MEDICARE TRIGGER
label: BODY

text: WASHINGTON, D.C. – Representative Pete Stark (D-CA), Chairman of the Ways and Means Health
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee, released the following remarks today after the House voted 231-184 to defuse the Medicare trigger for
label: BODY

text: this year:
label: BODY

text: “I want to thank my colleagues in the House for voting to turn off the Medicare trigger.  We in Congress are the
label: BODY

text: fiscal stewards of Medicare.  In general, we’ve done well by the program over its lifetime, but there’s
label: BODY

text: always more to do. When we enacted the Medicare Improvements for Patients and Providers Act earlier this month, we
label: BODY

text: actually met the fiscal objectives of this trigger. That bill passed with broad bipartisan support of 355-59 – a rare
label: BODY

text: show of unity in this Congress.  The veto override was an even stronger 383-41.
label: BODY

text: “The Congressional Budget Office has confirmed that both the new Medicare law and the President’s bill to
label: BODY

text: address the trigger would have the same effect regarding postponement of the threshold.
label: BODY

text: “Frankly, I oppose the entire concept of the trigger.  It is not sensible policy.  It was dreamed up behind closed
label: BODY

text: doors by Republicans eager to pacify their conservative colleagues in 2003 when they moved forward with the Medicare
label: BODY

text: prescription drug legislation. It is nothing more than a means to dismantle – not sustain – the Medicare
label: BODY

text: program by ending its guaranteed funding.
label: BODY

text: “We do NOT need an arbitrary, random number to tell us that we need to work together to ensure
label: BODY

text: Medicare’s fiscal health. When testifying before the Ways and Means Committee earlier this year,
label: BODY

text: Medicare’s Chief Actuary said, “I’m not aware of any specific technical rationale for” the
label: BODY

text: number.
label: BODY

text: “This is nothing more than a scare tactic designed by the Republicans to deliver a message to the public that
label: BODY

text: Medicare’s going broke.   Medicare is no more in danger of going broke that our defense department or any other
label: BODY

text: The Online Office of Congressman Pete Stark
label: BODY

text: http://www.stark.house.gov
label: BODY

text: Powered by Joomla!
label: BODY

text: Generated: 6 October, 2009, 23:36
label: BODY

text: governmental function.  We have no such trigger in law for limiting defense spending – and I challenge any of my
label: BODY

text: Republican colleagues to support a trigger policy for defense.
label: BODY

text: “Through the years, we have always acted – usually on a bipartisan basis -- to ensure Medicare’s
label: BODY

text: future.  That’s how we should continue to manage the program.
label: BODY

text: “Putting my strong opinions on the trigger aside, this entire debate today is unnecessary.  All this rule does is
label: BODY

text: override the process for the remainder of this Congress – and it does so for good reason.
label: BODY

text: “Given the fact that the newly enacted Medicare law postpones the trigger threshold, I urge my colleagues on both
label: BODY

text: sides of the aisle to join me in support of this rule change.  That law was enacted with broad bipartisan support.  This rule
label: BODY

text: change should as well.”
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND: Current law establishes three main sources of financing for Medicare: payroll taxes, general revenues,
label: BODY

text: and beneficiary premiums.  The Medicare Modernization Act created a new mechanism -- the “45 percent
label: BODY

text: trigger” -- to allegedly measure the adequacy of Medicare’s finances. The trigger looks at the amount of
label: BODY

text: Medicare spending financed by general revenues.
label: BODY

text: The trigger is set in motion if the Medicare Trustees project, in two consecutive annual Trustees Reports, that funding
label: BODY

text: from general revenues will exceed 45 percent of Medicare spending within a 7-year window.  If so, a “Medicare
label: BODY

text: funding warning” is issued, setting in motion various processes.  The President is required to submit legislation
label: BODY

text: within 15 days of the submission of the next budget, and there are expedited procedures in the House and Senate for
label: BODY

text: consideration of legislation, which may be the President’s bill or another bill. Both the 2006 and 2007 Trustees
label: BODY

text: reports projected general revenues would exceed the 45% threshold within the designated timeframe; thus, 2008 is the
label: BODY

text: first year that the “trigger” is pulled, setting in motion a requirement for the President to submit legislation.
label: BODY

text: In order to meet the target threshold, legislation needs to cut benefits, provider payments, shift more of the burden to
label: BODY

text: beneficiaries in the form of higher cost-sharing, or rely more heavily on payroll taxes.  The President sent such a bill to
label: BODY

text: Congress. It proposed raising drug benefit premiums for 1.5 million beneficiaries (4.5 percent of total beneficiaries) in
label: BODY

text: 2009, growing to 3.7 million beneficiaries (8.0 percent) hit with higher costs by 2018.  According to the Office of the
label: BODY

text: Actuary, more than 800,000 beneficiaries would drop out of the Administration’s drug program as a result of this
label: BODY

text: proposal.
label: BODY

text: The House-passed CHAMP Act, which passed the House by a vote of 225-204, would have repealed the trigger.
label: BODY

text: CHAMP’s provisions for reducing overpayments to private plans would also have extended Medicare’s
label: BODY

text: solvency.
label: BODY

text: The recently enacted Medicare Improvements for Patients and Providers Act (P.L. 110-235) will also extend
label: BODY

text: Medicare’s solvency and will result in a one-year delay in when Medicare financing crosses the 45 percent
label: BODY

text: threshold.  In fact, according to the Congressional Budget Office, its impact on Medicare financing is the same as to the
label: BODY

text: President’s bill.
label: BODY
